JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Giorgio Malinverni;Khanlar Hajiyev
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . At the material time the applicant was a ORG officer and worked as a military journalist on ORG newspaper PERSON ( “ Battle Watch ” ) . The applicant 's articles mainly focused on problems of environmental pollution and other issues related to the activity of ORG .

CARDINAL . According to the applicant , he also worked , on a freelance basis , for a NORP TV station , ORG , and a NORP newspaper , ORG , and supplied their representatives , in particular accredited correspondents Mr GPE . and Mr ORG with openly available information and video footage . The Government submitted in this connection , with reference to witness statements from the editor and deputy editor of PERSON , that the applicant had not been entrusted with any task of cooperating with Mr ORG , apart from assisting the latter in visiting NORP military units and apprising him of the professional activities of PERSON . According to the ORG , any further contacts with Mr ORG were maintained by the applicant of his own volition , and he did not report to his superiors on such contacts . The applicant insisted that his superiors had been aware of and accepted his contacts with NORP journalists .

CARDINAL . On DATE customs officers at FAC searched the applicant , who was about to leave on an official trip to GPE , and seized a number of his papers , on the ground that they allegedly contained classified information . Thereafter the applicant was allowed to continue his trip .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( ORG служба безопасности DATE “ the ORG ” ) brought criminal proceedings against the applicant in connection with the above episode , and apprehended him on his return from GPE . The applicant was then escorted to pre - trial detention centre FAC in GPE , where he was detained until his first conviction on DATE .
CARDINAL . During TIME the ORG searched the applicant 's flat and seized his personal computer and a number of documents . The applicant 's computer was returned to him some time later .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was formally charged with treason through espionage . These charges were based on a preliminary expert opinion given by the ORG ' ORG ( Восьмое управление штаба NORP флота ) , which concluded that some of the documents seized on CARDINAL and DATE contained ORG secrets .

CARDINAL . On DATE a bill of indictment was served on the applicant . It stated that the applicant had committed treason , through espionage , by having collected , kept and transmitted CARDINAL items of information classified as secret to CARDINAL NORP nationals in DATE and DATE . The information in question included a draft article by the applicant on the decommissioning of NORP nuclear submarines , a copy of a report on the financial situation of ORG , a copy of several pages of a manual on searching for and rescuing space craft by the ORG , a report on decommissioning and keeping afloat of NORP nuclear submarines , a questionnaire on re - processing of liquid rocket fuel , a list of accidents on NORP nuclear submarines , a copy of several pages of a report on decommissioning of weapons and armaments , a map of the territory of military unit no . DATE , and handwritten notes made by the applicant at a meeting held at the headquarters of ORG on DATE . The indictment further stated that the applicant had orally divulged information concerning the time and place of the departure of a trainload of spent nuclear fuel .
CARDINAL . The indictment was based on reports of DATE and DATE prepared by CARDINAL expert groups appointed by ORG ( Восьмое управление GPE Министерства обороны ) .

CARDINAL . By a judgment of DATE ORG reclassified the offence and convicted the applicant of abuse of power , having found it unproven that the applicant had actually transmitted ORG secrets to foreign nationals . The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . By virtue of an LAW of DATE the applicant was discharged from serving this sentence and released in the courtroom .
CARDINAL . The applicant , his lawyers and the prosecuting party appealed against the first - instance judgment .
CARDINAL . On DATE the Military Section of ORG of GPE ( ORG коллегия LOC – “ the ORG ” ) quashed the judgment of DATE on the grounds of the trial ORG for a fresh examination .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date , following ORG request , ORG appointed CARDINAL experts and ORG appointed an expert . The experts were asked whether the items of information listed in the indictment contained ORG secrets .

CARDINAL . On DATE the experts submitted their report , stating that CARDINAL out of the CARDINAL items in question were of “ restricted distribution ” , whilst the other CARDINAL contained ORG secrets . According to the applicant , in defining whether the disclosed information contained ORG secrets , the experts had applied ORG unpublished Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE , Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL:CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE and LAW CARDINAL of LAW , enacted on DATE and amended on DATE . In the applicant 's submission , he had access to Decree no . CARDINAL , read it and signed a document to the effect that he had read it in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG convicted the applicant of treason through espionage under LAW .

CARDINAL . As regards the actus reus of the offence , the court found that in DATE the applicant had established friendly relations with a NORP journalist , Mr GPE , and provided him with information , at the latter 's requests , in exchange for regular payments . In DATE , in his telephone conversations with the applicant , Mr ORG had repeatedly expressed his interest in the military exercises that were being conducted by ORG at that time , especially their particular features and any differences from previous exercises . The judgment further stated :

“ On DATE , on an official invitation , [ the applicant ] , as a representative of the ORG newspaper , attended a meeting of ORG , where he learned that an appraisal of the results of the military exercises of ORG was scheduled for DATE .

On DATE [ the applicant ] , with the intention of obtaining classified information on the said exercises and subsequently transferring it to [ Mr ORG ] , arrived at the headquarters of ORG . Although he was not included in the list of persons authorised to participate in the appraisal of the tactical training exercises , the applicant attended the meeting and collected information disclosing the actual names of highly critical and secured military formations and units , including military - intelligence units , that had taken part in the exercises and information disclosing the means and methods of protection of classified data by radio electronic warfare units that had participated in the exercises . Under section CARDINAL paragraphs CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) of DATE , as amended by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the List of Information classified as ORG approved by Decree no . DATE of the President of GPE of DATE , [ the impugned information ] was classified as ORG secrets .

For the same purpose , namely for communicating it to [ Mr ORG ] , the applicant then unlawfully kept this information ... On DATE the handwritten notes made by [ the applicant ] during [ the meeting of DATE ] were found and seized at his place of residence .
According to a report by a forensic expert , the handwritten text in those notes was made by [ the applicant ] , which the latter has not denied in court . ”

CARDINAL . The court based its findings on statements by a number of witnesses , CARDINAL recordings of the applicant 's telephone conversations with Mr ORG made by the ORG in DATE , and the expert report of DATE , insofar as it stated that the applicant 's handwritten notes contained information classified as secret . In particular , the court noted with regard to the expert report of DATE :

“ ... The experts concluded that [ the applicant 's ] notes contained , in summary fashion , information on the composition of the groups of the naval forces which had taken part in the exercises , [ such information ] disclosing the actual names of highly critical and secured military formations and units , including military intelligence units , which constituted a ORG secret under LAW , paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) of DATE , as amended by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE and paragraph CARDINAL of ORG constituting ORG , approved by Decree no . DATE of the President of GPE of DATE .

Also , the experts concluded that [ the applicant 's handwritten notes ] in summary fashion ... disclosed information on the activities of radio electronic warfare units , and notably on means and methods of protection of classified data , which constituted a ORG secret under LAW , paragraph CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of GPE , no . CARDINAL of DATE , as amended by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE and paragraph CARDINAL of ORG classified as ORG , approved by Decree no . DATE of the President of GPE of DATE .

... The court finds that [ the experts ' ] conclusions that [ the applicant 's ] notes on the exercises contain information disclosing the actual names of highly critical and secured military formations and units of ORG , including military intelligence units and [ information on ] specific activities of radio electronic warfare units ... which constitutes ORG secrets , are consistent , well - reasoned and based on a correct application of the legislation ... ”

CARDINAL . The applicant confirmed that he had attended the meeting of DATE and made summary notes of speeches and reports of its participants , but pleaded not guilty and argued that he had lawfully attended the said meeting , since he had the right to receive and impart information as a journalist . The applicant insisted that he had had no intention of transferring this information to Mr ORG and had kept it in order to enrich his own knowledge on the latest developments in the ORG and to inform his subordinates thereof , and to report on the results of the military exercises in the ORG newspaper . The applicant stated that all his activities had fully complied with NORP legislation .

CARDINAL . As regards the applicant 's argument that he had the right to freedom of expression , and was therefore entitled to attend the meeting of DATE , the court noted that the right to information was not absolute and could be limited by law for the protection of national security . Under national law , military personnel 's right to information was limited in the interests of military service and , in particular , such personnel had an obligation not to disclose state or military secrets . As a serving officer , the applicant was bound by the legal provisions regulating the way in which servicemen accessed , collected , kept , imparted and published information classified as secret , and the way they communicated with foreign nationals .

CARDINAL . The court also rejected the applicant 's argument that he had made the impugned notes with a view to their publication in PERSON . In this respect the court noted that the applicant had been fully aware of the relevant regulations which prohibited publication of information disclosing the actual names of military formations and units , and there had therefore been no practical use for such information in the applicant 's publications .

CARDINAL . The court further examined the conclusions of the expert report of DATE in respect of the other items of information imputed to the applicant , compared them with the other materials of the case and rejected them as unreliable . In particular , the court stated that some of the pieces of information imputed to the applicant , including the list of accidents on NORP nuclear submarines and the map of the territory of military unit no . DATE , could be found in public sources , such as a military reference book on submarines , or a ORG report . In this respect the court noted that receiving , keeping and disseminating publicly accessible information was not punishable under the NORP legislation in force and that there was no practical need to classify information which could be found in public sources .
CARDINAL . The court thus acquitted the applicant of all the other charges listed in the indictment , some of them having been waived by the prosecuting party .

CARDINAL . In view of the fact that the applicant had a minor child , no criminal record and positive professional references and decorations , and given that his offence had caused no damage , since he had not transferred the impugned information , the court referred to the “ special - circumstances ” clause of LAW of LAW and sentenced the applicant to a term below the statutory minimum , namely , DATE imprisonment in a strict - security correctional colony , and deprivation of a military rank .

CARDINAL . In their appeal submissions the defence complained , inter alia , that the experts who had drafted the report of DATE had relied on unpublished Decree no . CARDINAL of ORG in asserting the classified nature of the impugned information . The defence argued that the use of Decree no . CARDINAL by the experts had resulted in the incorrect application of LAW by the first - instance court . They further argued that LAW had been applied retrospectively , since there had been no list of information constituting ORG secrets at the time of the commission of the offence in question . The defence also contended that , in any event , the information contained in the applicant 's notes had been accessible from public sources .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld the applicant 's conviction on appeal , having excluded a reference to the unlawfulness of his presence at the meeting of DATE and to the general unlawfulness of his off - duty contacts with foreign nationals .

CARDINAL . ORG noted that the question whether the applicant 's handwritten notes had contained ORG secrets had been thoroughly and objectively examined in the first - instance judgment . It confirmed that the trial court had based its judgment on the expert report of DATE , which had stated that “ information disclosing the actual names of highly critical and secured military formations and units and information on the presence among the participants in the military exercises of the military intelligence units and information on the means and methods of protection of classified data [ constituted ] ORG secrets under LAW , paragraphs CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW of GPE ( no . DATE ) of DATE , as amended by ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG classified as ORG , approved by Decree of the President of ORG no . CARDINAL of DATE , and paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL of ... Decree of ORG no . CARDINAL ” . The appellate court further noted that , when assessing the expert report of DATE , the trial court had rejected a number of its conclusions in which the experts had groundlessly stated that some of the impugned items of information had contained ORG secrets . ORG thus concluded that the first - instance court had critically assessed the expert report of DATE and had only relied on those conclusions which had been objectively confirmed during the trial .

CARDINAL . ORG also upheld the first - instance finding that the applicant 's intent to transfer the impugned information to Mr ORG had been proved by the recordings of his telephone conversations with the latter . The court further rejected the applicant 's argument that the information in his handwritten notes could have been found in public sources . In that connection it stated DATE with reference to the trial court 's finding – that “ no data concerning the actual names of highly critical and secured military units , ships and formations , and , in particular , military intelligence units , the means and methods of radio electronic warfare , as contained in [ the applicant 's ] handwritten notes , [ was ] openly published ” .

CARDINAL . The court also rejected the applicant 's argument that Decree no . CARDINAL had been unlawfully applied in his case , holding that this decree had been operative on the date that the applicant had committed his offence and was still in force .
CARDINAL . Finally , as regards the applicant 's argument that the law had been applied retrospectively in his case , ORG noted :

“ According to the decision of ORG DATE , ... the requirements of LAW of GPE are implemented in LAW of GPE of DATE , which defines the notion of ORG secrets and lists the information classifiable as ORG secrets . Later , on DATE , the List of Information classified as ORG secrets was enacted by Decree no . DATE of the President of GPE .

Since collecting and keeping secret information for its transfer to a foreign citizen , committed by [ the applicant ] , [ was ] a continuing criminal offence which was brought to an end on DATE , the [ first - instance ] court rightly applied the aforementioned legal instrument as well as LAW , as amended on DATE , in the examination of his case . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant unsuccessfully applied for supervisory review of his conviction .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was released on parole .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL ( High Treason ) of LAW , in force as of DATE , provides that high treason , that is , espionage , disclosure of ORG secrets , or assistance otherwise provided to a foreign state , a foreign organisation , or their representatives , by way of hostile activities undermining the external security of GPE , committed by a NORP citizen , shall be punishable by DATE imprisonment and confiscation of property .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW provides that everyone has the right to freely search , obtain , impart , generate and disseminate information by all lawful means and that a list of information constituting ORG secrets is to be defined by a federal statute .
CARDINAL . Federal Law on State Secrets no . CARDINAL - CARDINAL ( “ the State Secrets Act ” ) was enacted on DATE and entered into force on DATE . Section CARDINAL provided :
“ The following information may be classified as ORG secrets :
( CARDINAL ) information in the military field :
[ information ] about the location , actual names , organisational structure , armament , numerical strength of troops ...
( CARDINAL ) information in the field of intelligence , counter - intelligence and operational and search activities :
[ information ] about the means and methods of protection of classified data ... ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL set out the procedure for classifying information as ORG secrets . ORG to classify information was delegated to heads of ORG agencies . The law itself did not contain the list of such officials which was to be approved by the NORP President . The latter was also to approve ORG classified as ORG secrets , which was to be officially published . State agencies whose heads were competent to decide to classify information were to draw up extended lists of information that was to be classified as ORG secrets . LAW did not specify whether such “ extended lists ” could be made public .

CARDINAL . On DATE , CARDINAL and DATE ORG , noting that the absence of the list of classified information “ deprived the law - enforcement agencies of a legal basis for the performance of their duty to protect the security of the ORG , community and individuals ” , repeatedly petitioned the ORG to prepare for the President 's approval a draft decree containing the list of classified information .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President approved Decree no . CARDINAL on the List of Information classified as ORG . Paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the list provided for the classification of “ information disclosing the location , actual names , organisational structure , armament and numerical strength of troops , which is not subject to open declaration in accordance with the international obligations of the NORP Federation ” and “ information disclosing measures which are planned and/or being carried out to protect information from unauthorised access , foreign technical intelligences services and leaks through technical channels ” . They also designated ORG , ORG and several other ORG agencies as bodies authorised to classify such information .
CARDINAL . On DATE Federal Law no . CARDINAL amending the DATE LAW was enacted . The amendment was published and became operative on DATE . LAW was amended to read :
“ State secrets shall include : ...
( CARDINAL ) information in the military field :
[ information ] about the location , actual names , organisational structure , armament , numerical strength of troops ...
( CARDINAL ) information in the field of intelligence , counter - intelligence and operational and search activities :
[ information ] about the means and methods of protection of classified data ... ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG examined the compatibility of LAW of the RSFSR , then in force , with LAW , in so far as the former established criminal liability for ORG treason , and stated :

“ ... It follows that the ORG may classify as ORG secrets information in the field of defence and economic and other activities , disclosure of which is capable of undermining the national defence and security of the ORG . In this connection LAW of LAW provides that the list of information constituting ORG secrets is to be enacted in the form of a federal statute . The ORG may also determine the means and methods for the protection of ORG secrets , including by way of establishing criminal liability for its disclosure and communication to a foreign ORG .

However , by virtue of the above LAW provision , criminal liability for disclosure of ORG secrets to a foreign ORG is justified only on condition that the list of information constituting ORG secrets is established in an officially published and publicly accessible federal statute . Pursuant to LAW , no law - enforcement decision , including conviction by a court , may be grounded on an unpublished legal instrument .
The requirement of LAW of LAW is implemented in LAW of DATE , which defines the notion of ORG secrets and lists the information classifiable as ORG secrets .

Accordingly , establishing criminal liability for disclosure of ORG or military secrets to a foreign ORG is not incompatible with ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL , CARDINAL § DATE and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE GPE acquitted Mr Nikitin , a former naval officer , of charges under LAW ( High treason ) and CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( Divulging of information constituting ORG secrets ) of MONEY ( case no . MONEY ) . PERSON was accused , in particular , of having collected in DATE , and having transferred in DATE , information constituting ORG secrets . The court held as follows :
“ ... By virtue of the constitutional provisions , a list of information constituting ORG secrets was to be defined by a federal statute ...

There was no such statute at the time that Mr Nikitin committed the alleged offences ; Decree no . DATE of the President of GPE of DATE was the only legal instrument which began regulating legal relations in the field of the protection of ORG secrets .
LAW of GPE of DATE , which was subsequently subjected to considerable amendments , constitutes the federal statute mentioned in LAW of LAW .

However , LAW prescribes the definition of the list of information constituting ORG secrets by a federal statute . This requirement of the LAW was only complied with in full when LAW was amended in DATE to include in section CARDINAL the list of information constituting ORG secrets instead of the list of information which could be classified as ORG secrets , which was mentioned in the [ original version ] of the PERSON .

By virtue of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW , the list of information constituting ORG secrets must be approved by the President . ... By virtue of section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW in its version of DATE and as amended on DATE [ the list ] will be published and may be revised as and when needed .

An analysis of LAW ( irrespective of its different versions ) indicates that [ the LAW ] itself does not establish any degree of secrecy ; in other words it does not classify any information , since it is in accordance with a special procedure provided for in section CARDINAL of the Act that information can be classified as secret ...

This also means that , in its original version , section CARDINAL of the LAW can not serve as the sole basis for charging [ a person ] with espionage or disclosure of ORG secrets . It must be supplemented with other legal instruments .
It is [ in particular ] Decree no . DATE of the NORP President of DATE which [ was ] used in the present case as [ a legal instrument ] in addition to LAW ] ...
The materials of the case reveal that PERSON ended his activity ... in DATE .
LAW of DATE had not yet entered into force ...

Accordingly , section CARDINAL of the LAW ( in the version that existed at the time when the defendant committed the acts imputed to him ) can not be used as a basis for bringing formal charges without supplementary legal instruments which would have formed a proper legal basis for an accusation ... such legal instruments can be applied on condition that they were officially published and entered into force prior to the commission of the acts imputed to PERSON .

... In view of the above , the court finds that any citizen of GPE ... does not ( did not ) have any real possibility of determining whether information constitutes a ORG secret unless such information is included in the list of information constituting a ORG secret defined by a federal statute or approved by a decree of the NORP President ...

The new version of LAW ... of DATE brought the LAW into compliance with the requirements of the LAW , and consequently , only then did it become possible to apply section CARDINAL of LAW independently , that is , without referring to the List of Information classified as ORG enacted by decree of the NORP President on DATE .

Accordingly , in the period from DATE until DATE there was no statutory definition of information constituting ORG secrets , and therefore classifying any information as secret during the period under consideration ... was arbitrary and not based on law . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld Mr PERSON 's acquittal in the following terms :

“ Having acquitted PERSON for the lack of constitutive elements of a criminal offence in his acts , the [ first - instance ] court proceeded from the premise that DATE and DATE there had been no statutory definition of information constituting ORG secrets , with the result that the qualification of PERSON Nikitin 's acts by the investigating bodies had not been based on law .

By virtue of LAW of LAW , which was enacted on DATE and was in force during the period when PERSON committed the alleged offences , the list of information constituting ORG secrets was to be defined in a federal statute . Such a list was first defined in the federal law introducing changes and amendments to LAW of GPE of DATE .

Taking into account that during the period when PERSON committed the alleged acts , there was no list of information constituting ORG secrets that met the requirements of the LAW , the information that he had collected ... and disclosed ... can not be said to have contained ORG secrets ... As the actus reus of the offences under ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Criminal Code refers only to acts involving ORG secrets , the same acts involving other information can not be held to be high treason and disclosure of ORG secrets ...

... The [ State Secrets ] Act [ in its DATE version ] could not have been applied to Mr Nikitin as it did not contain the list of information constituting ORG secrets , since section CARDINAL of that PERSON referred only to information that could be classified as ORG secrets . However , LAW required that the said list be established in a federal statute . As section CARDINAL of LAW of DATE and LAW refer to different subjects , the court can not agree with the argument of [ the prosecuting party ] to the effect that the difference between these provisions is merely semantic ... ”

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE quashed on appeal , and remitted for a fresh examination to a trial court , the sentence of PERSON PERSON , a former employee of ORG , who had been charged with offences under LAW . It found as follows :

“ In finding [ the applicant ] guilty of the offence under LAW , the [ first - instance ] court noted that ... DATE and DATE [ the applicant ] had ... communicated information and documents containing ORG secrets to the NORP intelligence service . The [ first - instance ] court only gave a general list of information and documents ... , without specifying which information and documents [ the applicant ] had communicated , and when . As the offences imputed to [ the applicant ] were continuous and spanned the period from DATE to DATE , during which time the NORP laws evolved , the determination of these issues is of crucial importance for the case .

Pursuant to LAW ... the list of information constituting ORG secrets was to be defined in a federal statute . Such a list was first established in the federal law of DATE introducing changes and amendments to LAW of GPE . Hence , until DATE there was no list of information constituting ORG secrets that met the requirements of the LAW . As there is no indication in the judgment about the time when [ the applicant ] transmitted the information and documents , it is impossible to reach the correct conclusion as to which of the offences imputed to the applicant were committed during the period when the federal law containing the list of ORG secrets and compatible with the requirements of the LAW was in force . ”
